root.pub-comments: “The question whether those languages labelled “Eastern Oceanic” constitute a subgroup of Oceanic was not a central concern of this study. […] The validity and precise membership of the subgroup is likely to remain uncertain until additional delimiting evidence is found, and better descriptions appear for many of the poorly recorded Oceanic languages” (Pawley 1972:135).
root.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “Like Southeast Solomonic, this large grouping is not supported by enough evidence to be fully convincing. At present it rests on grammatical arguments alone. However, these are on the whole more substantial than those found for Southeast Solomonic” (Pawley 1972:110).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: According to Pawley, Rotuman appears to have no very close relatives (1972:21). “Rotuman satisfies some of the criteria for inclusion [in] Eastern Oceanic and in the North Hebridean-Central Pacific subgroup of Eastern Oceanic. While there is some evidence for assigning Rotuman, to Central Pacific, at least one strong argument [e.g. extensive borrowing from two Polynesian sources (1972:129) and lack of phonological innovations shared by Polynesian and Fijian (1972:131)] is against it. Although no evidence has been encountered suggesting it belongs to a low-order other than Central Pacific, the position of Rotuman within Eastern Oceanic remains in doubt” (Pawley 1972:133).
child.geography: spoken on an island some 260 miles north of Fiji
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “It was noted that while the case for subgrouping Rotuman with Polynesian and Fijian appears, on present evidence, to be weak, certain of the grammatical arguments advanced by Grace do provide substantial support for a Fijian-Polynesian grouping” (Pawley 1972:119).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “Western Fijian is here represented here by Wayan, spoken on Waya Island, the southernmost member of the Yasawa Islands which lie off northwest Viti Levu” (Pawley 1972:21).
child.geography: spoken on Waya Island, southernmost of the Yasawa group, lying off the northwest coast of Viti Levu
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “Eastern Fijian is represented here by Standard Fijian, also called Bauan. This modern lingua franca is the descendant of the dialect of Bau Island and a number of closely related dialects spoken in southeast Viti Levu and offshore islands, and in the group of islands known as Lomaiviti” (Pawley 1972:21).
child.geography: native to Bau Island, Southeast Viti Levu
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken in the New Hebrides-Banks-Torres archipelago
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “The two Epi Is. Languages, Baki and Tasiko, also form a well-marked subgroup. These lower-order groupings will not be treated here, although evidence for them can readily be found in the data sections” (Pawley 1972:117).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken in the southwest and southeast corners of Epi Island
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken in the southwest and southeast corners of Epi Island
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: Node not named by author. “Two of these [Central New Hebrides languages] are obviously closely related: Nguna and Sesake” (Pawley 1972:117).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken on Sesake Island, between Epi and Efate
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: According to Pawley, Nguna is widely used as a lingua franca of the Central New Hebrides (1972:22).
child.geography: native to Nguna Island, off northwest Efate
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “There is a small amount of evidence for including the Malekula language, Aulua, in a wider subgroup along with these four languages” (Pawley 1972:117).
child.geography: spoken in southeast Malekula
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “Within North Hebrides-Banks it is difficult to isolate clearcut lower-order groupings. Many intersecting isoglosses testify to the uneven diffusion of innovations over a lengthy period, in accordance with Schmidt's wave theory. As a general rule, however, a New Hebrides-Banks language will be found to resemble its nearest New Hebrides-Banks neighbours more closely than geographically distant languages” (Pawley 1972:115).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken on the Mota (Sugarloaf) Islands, in the Banks Islands

child.geography: spoken on the central west coast of Espiritu Santo
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken in the northwest of Santa Maria Island, in the Banks Islands
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken in the eastern part of Saddle Island, in the Banks Islands
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken on Tangoa Island, off the south coast of Espiritu Santo
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken near Cape Lisburn, Southwest Espiritu Santo
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken on Merlav (Star) Island, the southernmost of the Banks group
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pri-name: Bay of St. Philip and St. James
child.geography: spoken around the Bay of St. Philip and St. James, on Espiritu Santo
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “While there is some evidence that Gilbertest belongs to the Nroth Hebridean-Central Pacific subgroup of Eastern Oceanic, it is not enough to be conclusive. Further comparative study involving a wider range of Micronesian languages should clarify the position of these languages” (Pawley 1972:135).
child.geography: spoken in the Gilbert Islands
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “The phonological materials strongly suggest that these six languages underwent a period of unity after their separation from other members of Eastern Oceanic” (Pawley 1972:107). Also, according to Pawley, evidence suggest that “if Cristobal-Malaitan languages do form a subgroup, the period of unity was relatively short and the proto-language broke up some 3,000 or more years ago into at least two divisions, one containing Bauro, and the other Lau and Toʔabaita.”
child.geography: San Cristobal – Malaita
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken in Central Malaita, between Coleridge Bay and Bina on the west coast, and between Fokana-koafo Bay and the Kwaibaita River on the east coast
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: native to the eastern end of Little Malaita
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken in the southeast of Malaita, near Naʔoni, Little Mala
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “It should be noted that other fairly similar dialects with the same name are spoken on the islands and in coastal enclaves in other part of Malaita” (Pawley 1972:22).
child.geography: spoken on the artificial islets off the northeast coast of Malaita
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “...all the San Cristobal languages may turn out to be assignable to a single large dialect complex” (Pawley 1972:107).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “The Bauro dialects, lying between Arosi and the Kahua dialects of Eastern San Cristobal (and probably mutually intelligible with both neighbouring dialect-groups) are represented here by Fagani” (Pawley 1972:22).
child.geography: spoken on the north coast of San Cristobal, just east of the Wango River
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “Arosi dialects are spoken west of the Wango River in approximately the western quarter of San Cristobal” (Pawley 1972:22).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “Longgu shows signs of extensive borrowing from Guadalcanal-Nggelic languages and its immediate relationships within Cristobal-Malaitan are less clear” (Pawley 1972:110).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “...there can be little doubt that there is a valid subgroup including Bugotu, Nggela and Vaturanga and excluding all other languages in the Eastern Oceanic sample. It also is likely, but not yet satisfactorily established, that Inakona has its immediate affinities with Bugotu, Nggela and Vaturanga” (Pawley 1972:107).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: Node not named by author.
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: According to Pawley, Bugotu is “a language quite closely related to Nggela” (1972:23).
child.geography: spoken in Southeastern Ysabel Island
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: Pawley notes that Nggela is better documented than other languages of Guadalcanal (1972:23).
child.geography: spoken on Florida Island
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.geography: spoken in the northwest of Guadalcanal
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.

child.pub-comments: “It is probable that Inakona, of South Guadalcanal, is more closely related to the first three languages above than to the Cristobal-Malaitan group” (Pawley 1972:103).
child.geography: spoken between Moli and Suga in the southwest of Guadalcanal
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1972. On the internal relationships of eastern Oceanic languages, Studies in Oceanic Culture History, vol. 3, 1-142. Honolulu, Hawaii: Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Department of Anthropology.
